titlestmt.title: The River of Life : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 9KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 102KB to 1800KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and ArchivesMarch 2011
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of thirty-three of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. All take their subjects from the New Testament and have been added to the twenty Old Testament subjects published in March 2010 as “Illustrations to the Bible, c. 1780-1824,” under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings. This new group is presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
Blake executed most of these New Testament water colors c. 1800-05 for his patron Thomas Butts. The exceptions are The Whore of Babylon of 1809 and The Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins in the Yale Center for British Art, datable to c. 1825. The subjects range from the childhood of Jesus to his ascension, the later history of his parents and one of his major followers, St. Paul, and a group of eight designs based on the Book of Revelation. While the illustrations of the life of Christ are fairly conventional in their subjects, in part because of the long tradition of picturing almost every event in the Gospels, individual motifs recall designs in Blake’s illuminated books and thus offer a window on Blake’s visual interpretation of the Bible. The illustrations of Revelation complement Blake’s intense engagement with apocalyptic events and images in his own poetry.
The selection of fifty-three biblical water colors now available in the Archive will be supplemented in the future with early works, such as Abraham and Isaac, datable to c. 1780, and will continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, such as Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color
objinfo.framelines: 5The space between the two inner-most framing lines is tinted light reddish-brown. The framing lines were probably drawn by Blake.

provenance.name: Tate Collection
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts, c 1805; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; by inheritance in 1862 to Captain Frederick J. Butts; the widow of F. J. Butts; sold April 1906 through Carfax & Co. to W. Graham Robertson; bequeathed by Robertson in 1949 to the Tate Gallery, now Tate Collection.

objnote.p: Blake signed the work lower left with his monogram and inscribed a reference to the passage illustrated, lower right. See the textual transcription. The framing lines are probably also by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This water color illustrates Revelation 22:1-2: "And he shewed me a pure river of water of life, clear as crystal." Dominating the center of the design is the river referenced in the text. Six figures stand on, hover just above, or swim in the river. The leftmost figure is that of a gowned man, facing away and to the right in profile. He has long hair and holds a small horn or trumpet that he presumably plays. He has his arms at his sides, but bent upward. His right leg is bent backward and on tiptoe, suggesting that he is walking, perhaps on the top of the water. The figure second from the left is that of a nude child, facing down and away but looking up and to the right in profile. The child is possibly male(?) and is swimming, with his left leg bent and his left arm raised horizontally. His right arm is raised at 135 degrees and is held by the figure to the right. This figure, third from the left, may be that of an adult male(?), gowned and with long hair. He faces away and his legs are bent as he swims, with his arms raised at 45 degrees. In each hand, he holds the hands of the children swimming by his side. The third figure from the right is a nude male(?) child with short hair, facing away. He swims with his legs bent slightly and his arms raised at 135 degrees. His left arm is being held by the male swimmer to the left. The figure second from the right may be that of a gowned female with curly hair pulled up. She(?) appears to be wearing a cloth band on her head and holds a plate or bowl in her left hand. Alternatively, she may be holding a knife and, like the Fate Atropos, is cutting the thread of life although no thread is pictured. She faces forward and down, bending forward as her lower body faces right and her upper body faces left. She may be looking at the plate or knife that she holds. Her legs are both bent slightly and her left arm is raised horizontally. She may be standing on the water. The rightmost figure of the group may be a gowned female with long hair pulled up into a bun, facing away and to the left. She may be walking, as indicated by her left leg, which is bent back and on tiptoe. Her arms are at her side but bent and she holds a flute that she may be playing. One figure hovers or flies above the river, a nude male facing down, forward, and to the left. His legs are both bent and his left arm is raised at 45 degrees, with his right arm raised vertically. He may be pointing with both hands. His hair is slightly curly. In the midground, on the right bank of the river is a building with a decorative pilaster and capitol by an open door. The branches of a leafy and fruit-laden tree extend above the building. Wrapped around the rightmost tree is a vine bearing grape-like clusters of fruit. Clustered around this building are four gowned figures. The leftmost figure is an old male with curly hair and a long beard. He faces forward and holds a book under his right arm, which is at his side. The second figure from the left may be a male with short, curly hair who bends his right arm and holds it against his chest. He faces forward and looks to the left, in profile. The second figure from the right is a child, perhaps with short hair. Its gender is indeterminable. It faces forward and its left arm is at its side. The rightmost figure is that of an old man with long hair and a beard. He faces left, in profile and slightly away, looking down. His arms are bent and he holds what may be loose pieces of paper or a book. In the midground on the left river bank is a house with pilasters and decorative capitols on either side of an open doorway, as well as a large window with glass panes. Above the window are pictures of two or three floating figures holding hands. There are slight suggestions of such figures above the door. Either side of the building are two leafy and fruit-laden trees. There are four figures clustered in front of the building. The leftmost figure wears a gown and faces forward and right, looking away. This figure may be a male with short hair. His legs may be crossed as his left foot protrudes from under the right side of his hem; he may be wearing a shoe. His right arm is raised horizontally and he points with his right hand. The second figure from the left is a gowned female with her long hair at least partly pulled up. She stands, facing forward and to the right and looking down. Her left foot protrudes from below the hem of her gown. Her arms are bent upward and perhaps crossed as she holds an infant. The figure second from the right of this group is an infant with short hair. It is of indeterminable gender and lies, facing left, up, and slightly away. It may be wrapped in a cloth. The rightmost figure of this group faces left and looks up. She has long hair and wears a gown. She stands on tiptoe with her right arm raised vertically, perhaps reaching for some fruit. In the background on the left river bank is a building with three pillars visible. To the left of these three pillars may be another pillar, or tree trunk. There is a leafy tree extending above and to the right side of the structure. There are two figures of indeterminate gender, facing forward, standing to the right of the three pillars. In the background on the right river bank stand two gowned and winged angels of indeterminable gender, facing away. Right of the angels are at least two tree trunks and leafy branches. The river banks appear to be sandy or grassy. A hill is visible in the background, on the right of a large sun that dominates the top of the design, emanating beams of light. The position of the sun on the horizon may indicate sunrise or sunset. Around the sun stand or hover five winged and gowned angels, facing forward. In between the second and third, third and fourth, and fourth and fifth angels from the left hover pairs of embracing figures. These figures may be nude and face each other, with the left figure of each pair facing right and the right figure of each pair facing left. Their bodies are horizontal.

component.illusobjdesc: Six figures stand on, hover just above, or swim in the River of Life. The leftmost figure is that of a gowned man, facing away and to the right in profile. He has long hair and holds a small horn or trumpet that he presumably plays. He has his arms at his side but bent upward. His right leg is bent backward and on tiptoe, suggesting that he is walking, perhaps on the top of the water.

Six figures stand on, hover just above, or swim in the River of Life. The figure second from the left is a nude male(?) child, facing down and away but looking up and to the right in profile. He is swimming, with his left leg bent and his left arm raised horizontally. His right arm is raised at 135 degrees and held by the figure to the right.

Six figures stand on, hover just above, or swim in the River of Life. The figure third from the left may be that of an adult male(?), gowned and with long hair. He faces away and down. His legs are bent as he swims, with his arms raised at 45 degrees and each hand holding that of a child to the side of him. His feet are prominent.

Six figures stand on, hover just above, or swim in the River of Life. The figure from the right is that of a nude male(?) child with short hair, facing away, and down. He swims with his legs bent slightly and his arms raised at 135 degrees. His left hand is held by the figure to his left.

Six figures stand on, hover just above, or swim in the River of Life. The figure second from the right may be that of a gowned female with curly hair that is possibly pulled up. She(?) may be wearing a piece of cloth on her head and holds a plate or bowl in her left hand. Alternatively, she may be holding a knife and, like the Fate Atropos, is cutting the thread of life although no thread is pictured. She faces forward and down, bending forward as her lower body faces right and her upper body faces left. She may be looking at the plate or knife that she holds. Her legs are both bent slightly and her left arm is raised horizontally. She may be standing on the water.

Six figures stand on, hover just above, or swim in the River of Life. The rightmost figure of the group may be a gowned female with long hair pulled up into a bun, facing away and to the left. She may be walking, as indicated by her left leg, which is bent back and on tiptoe. Her arms are at her side but bent and she holds a flute that she may be playing.

One figure hovers or flies above the river, a nude male facing down, forward, and to the left. His legs are both bent and his left arm is raised at 45 degrees, with his right arm raised vertically. He may be pointing with both hands. His hair may be curly.
The eponymous River of Life runs down the center of the design.

On the right bank of the river is a house with a decorative pilaster and capitol by an open doorway. In the midground on the left river bank is a house with pilasters and decorative capitols either side of an open doorway, as well as a large window with glass panes. Above the window are pictures of two or three floating figures holding hands. There are slight suggestions of such figures above the door. In the background on the left river bank is a building with three pillars visible.

Two mostly leafless trees with large round fruit like oranges as well as vines and bunches of grape-like fruit wrapped around its branches stand along the left side of the river bank. Another such tree stands on the right side of the river bank. In the background, several leafy trees are visible. The river banks appear to be sandy or grassy. A grass-covered hill is visible in the background on the right, next to the large sun.
A large sun dominates the top of the design, emanating beams of light. The position of the sun on the horizon may indicate sunrise or sunset.
Around the sun stand or hover five winged and gowned angels, facing forward. Each appears to have two pairs of wings.

In between the second and third, third and fourth, and fourth and fifth standing angels from the left that stand around the sun hover pairs of embracing figures. These figures may be nude and face each other. Their bodies are horizontal.

In the midground on the left river bank stand four figures. The leftmost figure wears a gown and faces forward and right, looking away. This figure may be a male with short hair. His legs may be crossed as his left foot protrudes from under the right side of his hem; he may be wearing a shoe. His right arm is raised horizontally and he points with his right hand.

In the midground on the left river bank stand four figures. The second figure from the left is a gowned female with her long hair at least partly pulled up. She stands, facing forward and to the right and looking down. Her left foot protrudes from below the hem of her gown. Her arms are bent upward and perhaps crossed as she holds an infant.

In the midground on the left river bank stand four figures. The second figure from the right is an infant with short, perhaps curly, hair. It is of indeterminable gender and lies, facing left, up, and slightly away. It may be wrapped in a cloth.

In the midground on the left river bank stand four figures. The rightmost figure of this group faces left and looks up. She has long hair and wears a gown. She stands on tiptoe with her right arm raised vertically, perhaps reaching for some fruit.

In the background on the left side of the river bank stand two gowned figures of indeterminable gender, facing forward. Both appear to have their arms at their sides. The rightmost figure may look left slightly.
In the background on the right side of the river bank stand two gowned and winged angels of indeterminable gender, facing away.

In the foreground on the right side of the river bank stand four gowned figures. The leftmost figure is an old male with curly hair and a long beard. He faces forward and may hold a book under his right arm, which is at his side.

In the foreground on the right river bank stand four gowned figures. The second figure from the left may be a male with short, curly hair who bends his right arm and holds it against his chest. He faces forward and looks to the left, in profile, to the figure next to him.

In the foreground on the right river bank stand four gowned figures. The second figure from the right is that of a child, perhaps with short hair. Its gender is indeterminable. It faces forward and its left arm is at its side.

In the foreground on the right river bank stand four gowned figures. The rightmost figure is that of an old man with long hair and a beard. He faces left, in profile, and slightly away, looking down. His arms are bent and he holds what may be loose pieces of paper or a book.
